required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Incidence of Headache Following an Unintentional Dural Puncture
clinical_study.official_title: Incidence of Post-Dural Puncture Headache Following Unintentional Dural Puncture: A Randomized Trial of Intrathecal Morphine Versus Saline

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to evaluate the use of intrathecal morphine administration following an unintentional dural puncture, to decrease the incidence of post dural puncture headaches (PDPH) in obstetric patients.

detailed_description.textblock:
Unintentional dural puncture is a known risk of neuraxial techniques, occurring in roughly 1% of all epidural catheter placements. The incidence of post dural puncture headaches(PDPH) after unintentional dural puncture (UDP) is 50-80%. A PDPH is defined as a headache that occurs following a dural puncture, worsens within 15 minutes after sitting or standing and improves within 15 minutes after lying, with at least one of the following: neck stiffness, tinnitus, hypacusia, photophobia, or nausea. The headache develops within 5 days after dural puncture and resolves either spontaneously within 1 week or within 48 hours after effective treatment of the spinal fluid leak.
The rates of PDPH following unintentional dural puncture with placement of an intrathecal catheter will be compared in two groups: intrathecal morphine (treatment) versus intrathecal saline (control) administered 1-2 hours after delivery, followed by immediate catheter removal. Patients randomized to the treatment group (morphine) will receive preservative-free morphine 0.3 mL (150 mcg) intrathecally. Those randomized to the control group will receive normal saline 0.3 mL intrathecally. After administration of intrathecal morphine, all patients will have their respirations monitored every hour for a period of 12 hours and then every two hours for a period of 12 hours. On postpartum days 1-5, all patients will be visited daily while inpatient and/or contacted by phone after discharge from the hospital.
PDPH can lead to significant morbidity and negatively impact patient satisfaction with postpartum recovery. Along with headache, patients may develop cranial nerve palsy during the postpartum period leading to permanent disability. In addition, new mothers are unable to bond with their babies due to headache and associated symptoms of nausea, vomiting and limited mobility secondary to pain. Therefore, an effective intervention to decrease the risk of PDPH after UDP would be useful.

primary_outcome.measure: Participants Who Report Post Dural Puncture Headaches
primary_outcome.description: Participants who report post dural puncture headaches from delivery to postpartum day 5

secondary_outcome.measure: Severity of Post Dural Puncture Headache
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Time of unintentional dural puncture to postpartum day 5
secondary_outcome.description: Severity of post dural puncture headache on a numerical rating scale 0= no pain and 10= worst pain imaginable from the time of delivery to postpartum day 5.
Treatment method completed for unintentional dural puncture headache.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Cranial Nerve Symptoms
secondary_outcome.description: The number of participants who experience cranial nerve symptoms up to 5 days after the unintentional dural puncture.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: After first epidural blood patch to 5 days after delivery
secondary_outcome.description: Repeated epidural blood patch for headache pain after unintentional dural puncture.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Dural puncture to 5 days after delivery
secondary_outcome.description: Presenting day of headache after unintentional dural puncture

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Duration in Days of Headache After Unintentional Dural Puncture.
secondary_outcome.description: The duration in days of headaches the participants experience after an unintentional dural puncture

secondary_outcome.measure: Greatest Level of Headache Pain Experienced With the Unintentional Dural Puncture
secondary_outcome.description: Greatest reported headache pain associated with unintentional dural puncture reported on a scale of 0= no pain to 10= worst pain imaginable.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Insertion time to removal in minutes
secondary_outcome.description: Intrathecal catheter dwell time(time from insertion to time of removal in minutes).

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Time of insertion of catheter to time catheter removed
up to 10 hours after intrathecal catheter placed
secondary_outcome.description: Mode of delivery of the baby (vaginal delivery or instrumented vaginal delivery)

arm_group.description: Patients randomized to the treatment group (morphine) will receive preservative-free morphine 0.3 mL (150 mcg) intrathecally.
Patients randomized to the control group will receive normal saline 0.3 mL intrathecally.

intervention.description: The drug will be prepared in tuberculin syringes. After thoroughly sanitizing the catheter port with a Chloroprep wipe and allowing adequate time for drying of the Chloroprep, the anesthesiologist will first attach a 3-mL syringe to the catheter port and aspirate to a volume of 1 mL. This syringe will then be removed from the port. The study drug will then be administered through the intrathecal catheter via the tuberculin syringe. The 3-mL syringe containing the aspirate will then be injected via the catheter, effectively flushing the study drug through the catheter. The intrathecal catheter will be removed immediately following the injection.

The drug will be prepared in tuberculin syringes. After thoroughly sanitizing the catheter port with a Chloroprep wipe and allowing adequate time for drying of the Chloroprep, the anesthesiologist will first attach a 3-mL syringe to the catheter port and aspirate to a volume of 1 mL. This syringe will then be removed from the port. The study drug will then be administered through the intrathecal catheter via the tuberculin syringe. The 3-mL syringe containing the aspirate will then be injected via the catheter, effectively flushing the study drug through the catheter. The intrathecal catheter will be removed immediately following the injection.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Postpartum patients following vaginal delivery
- Unintentional dural puncture
- Functioning intrathecal catheter
- Patients must be 18 years of age or older
- English speaking.
Exclusion Criteria:
- History of previous PDPH
- Body mass index BMI > 40 kg/m2
- History of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA)
- Morphine allergy
- Patients who receive Cesarean delivery

reference.citation: Apfel CC, Saxena A, Cakmakkaya OS, Gaiser R, George E, Radke O. Prevention of postdural puncture headache after accidental dural puncture: a quantitative systematic review. Br J Anaesth. 2010 Sep;105(3):255-63. doi: 10.1093/bja/aeq191. Epub 2010 Aug 3. Review.
Denny N, Masters R, Pearson D, Read J, Sihota M, Selander D. Postdural puncture headache after continuous spinal anesthesia. Anesth Analg. 1987 Aug;66(8):791-4.

Choi PT, Galinski SE, Takeuchi L, Lucas S, Tamayo C, Jadad AR. PDPH is a common complication of neuraxial blockade in parturients: a meta-analysis of obstetrical studies. Can J Anaesth. 2003 May;50(5):460-9.
Choi A, Laurito CE, Cunningham FE. Pharmacologic management of postdural puncture headache. Ann Pharmacother. 1996 Jul-Aug;30(7-8):831-9. Review.

Hartopp R, Hamlyn L, Stocks G. Ten years of experience with accidental dural puncture and post-dural-puncture headache in a tertiary obstetric anaesthesia department. Int J Obstet Anesth. 2010 Jan;19(1):118. doi: 10.1016/j.ijoa.2009.06.004. Epub 2009 Nov 28.
Angle P, Tang SL, Thompson D, Szalai JP. Expectant management of postdural puncture headache increases hospital length of stay and emergency room visits. Can J Anaesth. 2005 Apr;52(4):397-402.
Carbaat PA, van Crevel H. Lumbar puncture headache: controlled study on the preventive effect of 24 hours' bed rest. Lancet. 1981 Nov 21;2(8256):1133-5.
Sudlow C, Warlow C. Posture and fluids for preventing post-dural puncture headache. Cochrane Database Syst Rev. 2002;(2):CD001790. Review. Update in: Cochrane Database Syst Rev. 2013;7:CD001790.
Hakim SM. Cosyntropin for prophylaxis against postdural puncture headache after accidental dural puncture. Anesthesiology. 2010 Aug;113(2):413-20. doi: 10.1097/ALN.0b013e3181dfd424.
Carter BL, Pasupuleti R. Use of intravenous cosyntropin in the treatment of postdural puncture headache. Anesthesiology. 2000 Jan;92(1):272-4.

Ayad S, Demian Y, Narouze SN, Tetzlaff JE. Subarachnoid catheter placement after wet tap for analgesia in labor: influence on the risk of headache in obstetric patients. Reg Anesth Pain Med. 2003 Nov-Dec;28(6):512-5.
Charsley MM, Abram SE. The injection of intrathecal normal saline reduces the severity of postdural puncture headache. Reg Anesth Pain Med. 2001 Jul-Aug;26(4):301-5.

Cohen S, Amar D, Pantuck EJ, Singer N, Divon M. Decreased incidence of headache after accidental dural puncture in caesarean delivery patients receiving continuous postoperative intrathecal analgesia. Acta Anaesthesiol Scand. 1994 Oct;38(7):716-8.

Scavone BM, Wong CA, Sullivan JT, Yaghmour E, Sherwani SS, McCarthy RJ. Efficacy of a prophylactic epidural blood patch in preventing post dural puncture headache in parturients after inadvertent dural puncture. Anesthesiology. 2004 Dec;101(6):1422-7.
Eldor J, Gozal Y, Lavie A, Guedj P. Late postspinal headache treated with epidural morphine. Anaesthesia. 1990 Dec;45(12):1099.
Al-metwalli RR. Epidural morphine injections for prevention of post dural puncture headache. Anaesthesia. 2008 Aug;63(8):847-50. doi: 10.1111/j.1365-2044.2008.05494.x. Epub 2008 Jun 10.
Banks S, Paech M, Gurrin L. An audit of epidural blood patch after accidental dural puncture with a Tuohy needle in obstetric patients. Int J Obstet Anesth. 2001 Jul;10(3):172-6.
Olesen J, Steiner TJ. The International classification of headache disorders, 2nd edn (ICDH-II). J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry. 2004 Jun;75(6):808-11.

provided_document.document_type: Study Protocol and Statistical Analysis Plan

participant_flow.recruitment_details: 68 were consented to participate in the study . 2 withdrew and 3 were excluded for non-functional catheter.

group.title: Morphine
group.description: Patients randomized to the treatment group (morphine) will receive preservative-free morphine 0.3 mL (150 mcg) intrathecally. Morphine: The drug will be prepared in tuberculin syringes. After thoroughly sanitizing the catheter port with a Chloroprep wipe and allowing adequate time for drying of the Chloroprep, the anesthesiologist will first attach a 3-mL syringe to the catheter port and aspirate to a volume of 1 mL. This syringe will then be removed from the port. The study drug will then be administered through the intrathecal catheter via the tuberculin syringe. The 3-mL syringe containing the aspirate will then be injected via the catheter, effectively flushing the study drug through the catheter. The intrathecal catheter will be removed immediately following the injection.

The 3-mL syringe containing the aspirate will then be injected via the catheter, effectively flushing the study drug through the catheter. The intrathecal catheter will be removed immediately following the injection.

group.title: Total
group.description: Total of all reporting groups

category.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

measure.title: Body Mass Index (kg/m^2)
measure.description: Body mass index (BMI) is derived from the (weight) and height of the subject. The BMI is defined as the body mass divided by the square of the body height, and is expressed in units of kg/m^2.

measure.title: Nulliparous
measure.description: Number of participants who presented as nulliparous.

measure.title: Loss of resistance method
measure.description: Loss of resistance method of catheter placement (either air or saline) used by the operator.

measure.title: Intrathecal catheter depth (cm)
measure.description: The final depth of the placement of the catheter in centimeters.

measure.title: Unable to aspirate prior to administering study drug (n)
measure.description: The number of subjects whose intrathecal catheter were unable to be aspirated prior to study drug administration.

measure.title: Participants Who Report Post Dural Puncture Headaches
measure.description: Participants who report post dural puncture headaches from delivery to postpartum day 5

analysis.groups_desc: A sample size of 65 patients in each group would be required to achieve 80% power to detect this difference between intrathecal morphine and saline administration . Sample size of 64 per group achieve 80% power to detect a difference between the group proportions of 0.25. The proportion in the treatment group is assumed to be 0.5 under the null hypothesis and 0.25 under the alternative hypothesis. The proportion in the control group is .05.The significance level of the test was targeted at .05.

outcome.title: Severity of Post Dural Puncture Headache
outcome.description: Severity of post dural puncture headache on a numerical rating scale 0= no pain and 10= worst pain imaginable from the time of delivery to postpartum day 5.
outcome.time_frame: Time of unintentional dural puncture to postpartum day 5
outcome.population: 21 in the morphine group and 27 in the saline group experienced headaches.

group.title: Saline
group.description: Patients randomized to the control group will receive normal saline 0.3 mL intrathecally. Saline: The drug will be prepared in tuberculin syringes. After thoroughly sanitizing the catheter port with a Chloroprep wipe and allowing adequate time for drying of the Chloroprep, the anesthesiologist will first attach a 3-mL syringe to the catheter port and aspirate to a volume of 1 mL. This syringe will then be removed from the port. The study drug will then be administered through the intrathecal catheter via the tuberculin syringe. The 3-mL syringe containing the aspirate will then be injected via the catheter, effectively flushing the study drug through the catheter. The intrathecal catheter will be removed immediately following the injection.

measure.title: Intrathecal Catheter Dwell Time
measure.description: Intrathecal catheter dwell time(time from insertion to time of removal in minutes).
measure.units: Insertion to removal time in minutes

outcome.title: Intrathecal Infusion Volume
outcome.time_frame: Time of insertion of catheter to time catheter removed

group.title: Morphine
group.description: Patients randomized to the treatment group (morphine) will receive preservative-free morphine 0.3 mL (150 mcg) intrathecally. Morphine: The drug will be prepared in tuberculin syringes. After thoroughly sanitizing the catheter port with a Chloroprep wipe and allowing adequate time for drying of the Chloroprep, the anesthesiologist will first attach a 3-mL syringe to the catheter port and aspirate to a volume of 1 mL. This syringe will then be removed from the port. The study drug will then be administered through the intrathecal catheter via the tuberculin syringe. The 3-mL syringe containing the aspirate will then be injected via the catheter, effectively flushing the study drug through the catheter. The intrathecal catheter will be removed immediately following the injection.

The 3-mL syringe containing the aspirate will then be injected via the catheter, effectively flushing the study drug through the catheter. The intrathecal catheter will be removed immediately following the injection.

outcome.title: Mode of Delivery
outcome.description: Mode of delivery of the baby (vaginal delivery or instrumented vaginal delivery)
outcome.time_frame: up to 10 hours after intrathecal catheter placed

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.

clinical_results.limitations_and_caveats: The results of our study should only be interpreted in the context of its limitations. Our sample size is small and we stopped the study prior to meeting our original estimated sample size.
